list.name: Area2D
list.title: Detects when things enter and exit it
examples: Attaching a hurt box to a character so it can take damage
Attracting coins to the player when in range
Opening a chest when standing next to it and pressing a button
list.use_when: You want to create a perimeter that warns you when objects enter or exit it

list.name: GPUParticles2D
list.title: GPUParticles2D draws textures to create visual effects
examples: Creating dust puffs when a character lands on the ground
Making a torch or campfire with flames
Creating a trail behind a character moving fast
Making a special attack charging effect
Creating a healing beam
list.use_when: You want to create an explosion, fire, smoke, or other visual effects.

list.name: Camera2D
list.title: Controls what's on-screen in a 2d scene
examples: Making the view follow the player character with or without an offset
Shaking the screen when the player takes a hit
Zooming the view in and out to keep multiple entities on screen
list.use_when: You need to control the game view, make the view follow an entity, zoom in and out, or shake the screen

list.name: CharacterBody2D
list.title: Lets you code custom character movement
examples: Coding a side scroller character that can stomp enemies
Making your character stand on moving platforms
Creating a top down character that can push objects
list.use_when: You want to create a character or enemy that collides with the game world and moves in a specific way

list.name: Navigation2D
list.title: 2D navigation nodes help AIs find their way around obstacles
examples: Making enemies chase the player around walls and obstacles
Creating grid-based navigation for turn-based games
Making areas inaccessible for AIs with doors that can be unlocked
Having AIs avoid moving obstacles in real-time
list.use_when: You want AI characters to find paths around obstacles and navigate complex 2D environments

list.name: Line2D
list.title: Line2d draws lines
examples: Creating a trail for bullets or projectiles
Drawing a trajectory for a homing missile
Creating a tether between two objects
Drawing a path for a character to follow
list.use_when: You need to draw lines, curves, or trails in your game.

list.name: TileMapLayer
list.title: TileMapLayer draws levels using reusable tiles on a grid
examples: Creating side-scroller levels with automatic platform corner and edge transitions
Building strategy game boards where you place units on grid cells
Designing RPG worlds with different terrain types that blend together
Setting up lights and shadows in a grid-based game environment
Playing different sound effects based on what floor type the player walks on
list.use_when: You want to efficiently design levels using repeating tile patterns and grid-based layouts

list.name: RigidBody2D
list.title: RigidBody2D moves with physics
examples: Physics-based platformer character that bounces and tumbles
Explosive barrels that fly apart when hit
Collapsing tower structures like in Angry Birds
list.use_when: When you want realistic physics movement with forces, gravity, and collisions handled automatically. Choose over CharacterBody3D when you need physics-based interactions rather than precise manual control.

list.name: RayCast2D
list.title: Fires a ray that detects collisions
examples: Firing a laser beam that splashes on impact or that mines resources
Giving a line of sight to an enemy
Making an enemy or NPC detect obstacles in its path and steer around them
list.use_when: You need to detect if and where a line intersects with physics bodies

list.name: Path2D
list.title: Path2D and PathFollow2D constrain the movement of child nodes
examples: Moving units along paths generated by A* pathfinding
Making cards move along procedural curves
Making platforms follow complex movement patterns
Generating vector force fields for physics objects
Creating dynamic laser beam effects between points
list.use_when: You want to constrain objects to move along a predefined path or curve

list.name: RemoteTransform2D
list.title: RemoteTransform2D pushes its transform to another node
examples: Attaching UI elements to game characters
Creating mini-maps that track player position
Synchronizing distant visual effects with gameplay objects
list.use_when: Two nodes need to move together but are in different parts of the scene tree

list.name: VisibleOnScreenNotifier2D
list.title: VisibleOnScreenNotifier2D notifies when an object is on the screen
examples: Delete bullets when they go off-screen
Pause enemy AI when enemies are not visible
Trigger dialog warnings when hazards become visible
list.use_when: When you need to optimize off-screen objects, trigger behaviors based on visibility, or clean up projectiles that leave the screen

list.name: Area3D
list.title: Area3D detects when things enter and exit it
examples: Attaching a hurt box to a character so it can take damage
Attracting coins to the player when in range
Opening a chest when standing next to it and pressing a button
list.use_when: You want to create a space that warns you when objects enter or exit it

list.name: RigidBody3D
list.title: RigidBody3D moves with physics
examples: Physics-based platformer character that bounces and tumbles
Explosive barrels that fly apart when hit
Collapsing tower structures like in Angry Birds
list.use_when: When you want realistic physics movement with forces, gravity, and collisions handled automatically. Choose over CharacterBody3D when you need physics-based interactions rather than precise manual control.

list.name: RemoteTransform3D
list.title: RemoteTransform3D shares its transform with 3D nodes
examples: Attaching a camera to game characters
Making an entity follow a path
Mounting the player on a vehicle or creature
list.use_when: Two 3D nodes need to move together but are in different parts of the scene tree

list.name: Light3D
list.title: Light and shadows in 3D scenes
examples: Creating sunlight and moonlight with DirectionalLight3D
Making a flashlight with SpotLight3D
Setting up a day-night cycle
Lighting interior scenes with multiple light sources
Using LightmapGI for performance on low-end devices
list.use_when: You want to illuminate 3D scenes

list.name: VisibleOnScreenNotifier3D
list.title: VisibleOnScreenNotifier3D notifies when an object is visible to the camera
examples: Disable complex animations when objects are not visible
Change enemy AI behavior when off-screen
Show UI indicators for off-screen targets
list.use_when: When you need to optimize off-screen objects, trigger behaviors based on visibility, or create camera-aware AIs

list.name: Camera3D
list.title: Camera3D allows you to see in 3D space
examples: Creating a first-person camera that follows player movement
Making a third-person camera that orbits around the player
Increasing field of view when the player sprints
Smoothly moving the camera between different targets
Adding screen shake effects to increase impact
list.use_when: You want to see and manipulate the view in 3D environments

list.name: Path3D
list.title: Path3D and PathFollow3D constrain the movement of child nodes
examples: Moving units along paths generated by A* pathfinding
Moving cards from the player hand to the game board along randomly generated paths
Designing moving platforms that follow complex paths
Creating vector force fields that affect rigid bodies
Making a character grind on rails in a 3D environment
list.use_when: You want to constrain movement or rotation of objects along a smooth curve in 3D space

list.name: CSG
list.title: CSG nodes are helpful for building props and prototyping levels
examples: Carving doorways and windows from walls
Building pipes and cables that follow curved paths
Combining simple shapes to create more complex architectural structures
Prototyping game levels before creating final art assets
list.use_when: You want to quickly build 3D geometry for prototyping levels and props directly in the editor

list.name: Navigation3D
list.title: Navigation 3D collection of nodes shows you how to get from one place to another
examples: Making enemies chase the player around walls and obstacles
Creating grid-based navigation for turn-based games
Making areas inaccessible for AIs with doors that can be unlocked
Having AIs avoid moving obstacles in real-time
list.use_when: You want AI characters to find paths around obstacles and navigate complex 3D environments

list.name: GridMap
list.title: Use GridMap to create levels in a 3D grid out of cells
examples: Creating and erasing buildings on a city map
Building a race track editor with auto-connecting pieces
Procedurally placing dungeon rooms and corridors
list.use_when: You want to quickly create 3D levels by painting tiles on a grid

list.name: Label3D
list.title: Label3D displays text in 3D space
examples: Drawing an objective marker that floats in 3D space
Creating player name tags that follow characters in multiplayer
Adding emoji reactions above 3D characters
Displaying UI text that shows through other 3D objects
list.use_when: You want to display text that exists in 3D world and can follow 3D objects

list.name: RayCast3D
list.title: RayCast3D detects bodies along a line in 3D space
examples: Detecting if an AI turret has line of sight to the player
Checking for platforms and ledges a character can climb
Firing bullets or laser beams at targets
Creating enemy pathfinding systems
list.use_when: You want to check for objects along a line in 3D space

list.name: CharacterBody3D
list.title: CharacterBody3D lets you code custom 3D movement
examples: Creating a 3D platform character that can walk, jump, and stomp enemies
Designing a first-person controller for an FPS game
Making characters stick to and climb walls with wall jumping
Walking on rotating and moving platforms
Pushing rigid bodies with your character
list.use_when: You want to create a player or AI-controlled entity that interacts with the physics environment

list.name: MeshInstance3D
list.title: MeshInstance3D let you add 3d models to your games.
examples: Creating a forest with hundreds of trees scattered over a landscape
Adding props and decorations to 3D levels
Creating fast-rendering flocking birds or fish
Building procedural environments with scattered rocks and vegetation
list.use_when: You want to display 3D models and meshes in your scene

list.name: CanvasLayer
list.title: CanvasLayer: Renders children on a separate rendering layer
examples: Fixed HUD with health bars, minimap, and buttons that stay on screen during gameplay
Screen-wide transition effects like fade-to-black, wipe transitions, or loading overlays
Pseudo 3D effect for depth illusion
list.use_when: When you need UI elements that don't scroll with the camera, want to create layered visual effects with different render orders, or need to apply post-processing effects to specific screen regions

list.name: SubViewport
list.title: SubViewport: Render to texture for advanced visual effects
examples: Split-screen multiplayer games
3D portals showing other areas
UI elements overlaid on 3D characters
list.use_when: When you need multiple camera views, render-to-texture effects, or separate rendering contexts

list.name: AudioStreamPlayer
list.title: Plays sound and music
examples: Playing background music or looping ambiances
Playing footsteps sounds in sync with a character's animation
Playing voice-overs for dialogues
list.use_when: You need to play any audio in the game

list.name: Tween
list.title: Animates properties procedurally
examples: Animating items the player collects in the game world flying towards the user interface
Animating cards moving from a deck to different positions in the player's hand
Moving a character to the position of a mouse click in a point-and-click game
list.use_when: You want to animate a property of a node, and you don't know the start or end points of the animation in advance

list.name: Timer
list.title: Counts time and triggers events
examples: Creating a cooldown time for a special ability
Spawning enemies at regular time intervals
Implementing a game timer that you can pause and resume
list.use_when: You need to count time, delay code execution, or trigger events after a set amount of time once or repeatedly

list.name: AnimationPlayer
list.title: Plays and queues handmade animations
examples: Fading the screen to black
Designing an explosion animation for a weapon
Creating a gun reload animation
list.use_when: You need animations that have a known start and end point, and you want to control the timing of the animation

list.name: NinePatchRect
list.title: NinePatchRect lets you style user interface elements
examples: Creating resizable dialog boxes with a consistent border style
Making game cards or inventory slots with a nice frame
Building customizable window panels for game menus
list.use_when: You want to create scalable UI panels that keep clear borders and corners when resized

list.name: Button
list.title: Draws a button the player can press
examples: Navigating to different sub-menus from a game's main menu
Displaying items you can click and buy in a shop
Selecting a weapon or a skill by clicking on it in a shortcut bar
list.use_when: You need a button to start an action, make a choice, or provide information

list.name: BoxContainer
list.title: Creates rows and columns for your UI
examples: Aligning the options vertically in a menu
Arranging the player's Heads-Up Display along the top of the screen
Displaying a form where the player can enter their account name and password
list.use_when: You need to arrange UI nodes in rows or columns

list.name: LineEdit
list.title: LineEdit lets players input text
examples: Typing the player's character name during character creation
Creating a search bar to filter through a list of items
Building login forms with email and password validation
Making a chat message field for multiplayer games
list.use_when: You need players to type text input like their name, password, or chat messages

list.name: RichTextLabel
list.title: Displays formatted and animated text
examples: Displaying game dialogs with colored, bold, or animated text
Creating a chat log in a multiplayer game
Displaying a tooltip when the player hovers over a keyword
list.use_when: You want to display large amounts of text with formatting, animations, or interactions

list.name: PanelContainer
list.title: PanelContainer and margincontainer maximize control nodes
examples: Creating a speech bubble that dynamically scales to fit dialogue text
Drawing borders and shadows around game cards
Building inventory slots that hold draggable item icons
Making UI panels that resize with the window
Adding consistent padding around UI elements
list.use_when: You want to create a background panel or container that automatically resizes its children to fill available space

list.name: OptionButton
list.title: OptionButton lets the player select from a dropdown menu.
examples: Difficulty selector with Easy, Normal, Hard options
Custom game setup with map size, game mode, and time limit
Level-up menu for choosing character perks or skills
Weapon selector that changes the player's equipped item
list.use_when: You need players to choose one option from a predefined list of choices

list.name: ProgressBar
list.title: ProgressBar displays values as visual bars
examples: Creating health bars that decrease as the player takes damage
Building loading screens that show download or level loading progress
Displaying ability cooldowns that fill up over time
Creating experience bars that fill when the player earns experience points
list.use_when: You want to display a value as a visual bar, like health, energy, loading progress, or ability cooldowns

list.name: Label
list.title: Displays simple text
examples: Displaying dialogue lines that appear letter by letter
Showing the names of items and prices in a shop
Showing the player's score or the number of coins they have
list.use_when: You want to display text, and you don't need formatting or special effects
